coredata.dc:title: Determination of particle size in the range below 10 Å for ultrathin films of Pt/C
coredata.dc:creator: Guillén, Nilo
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The phenomenon of clustering and its influence on the catalytic activity of the Pt/C system is studied. Coverages of the order of 1012 atoms/cm2 were used. Calculations permit the estimation of the most active particles as dimers and other large particles of the B4 and B5 site types.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 129, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 22 August 1986 DETERMINATION OF PARTICLE SIZE IN THE RANGE BELOW 10 A FOR ULTRATHIN FILMS OF Pt/C Nilo GUILLEN Departamento de Fisica, Escuela de Fisica y Matematicas, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad Central de Venezuela. Apartado Postal 47906, Caracas, 1020-A, Venezuela Received 18 December 1985; in final form 12 June 1986 The phenomenon of clustering and its influence on the catalytic activity of the Pt/C system is studied. Coverages of the order of 1012 atoms/cm2 were used. Calculations permit the estimation of the most active particles as dimers and other large particles of the 84 and 85 site types. 1. Introduction Numerous recent studies have been concerned with the effect of particle size [1 ], as well as the design of theoretical and experimental methods for the determi- nation of size, in particular below 10 15 A [2]. The Pt C system has received special attention [3]. The modern techniques of electron microscopy and espe- cially that ofEXAFS, have proved to be powerful tools for the investigation of particles smaller than 15 A [4]. The study made by Lagarde et al. [5] de- serves special mention. In this study the phenomenon of clustering and its influence on the catalytic activity of the Pt/C system was investigated. Coverages of the order of 101 atoms/cm2 are used. For these coverages, the probability of deposition of isolated atoms and of particles with very few atoms is large. The study of small particles in this range (less than 10 A), is diffi- cult, even with modern methods such as electron mi- croscopy, EXAFS and field emission. In this study ex- amination of this range is proposed. A simple method is proposed, which uses hydrogen adsorption. Utilizing an Omegatron mass spectrometer for gas analysis, it was possible to carry out an investigation of the aver- age size of these particles, their interactions with the substrate and the dynamics of cluster formation. 2. Experimental Spectrally pure platinum films were evaporated un- der ultrahigh vacuum conditions on a spectrally pure carbon film. The carbon film had a width of approxi- mately 150 A and had been vaporized under ultrahigh vacuum conditions according to a known method [6]. The carbon film had a graphite structure, with small crystals. After having been tempered at 400 C, its electrical resistance was approximately 3 k0. Platinum, used as a catalyst was evaporated under ultrahigh vacu- um conditions (<5 X 10~10 Torr). A method based on the fact that the electric resistance of a pure carbon film varies directly with the amount of vaporized met- al (Pt in this case), was used for dosification [7]. The proportionality between the additional conductivity of the metal film and its "width" from 5 X 10~4 to 2 monolayers (one monolayer = 1.2 X 1015 atoms/cm2), is obeyed very well for temperatures greater than 250 K. The power of resolution of the method permits de- tecting, controlling and vaporizing coverages up to 2 X 10 atoms/cm2. For the analysis of the gases in- volved in the reactions, an Omegatron mass spectrom- eter without memory effect, of the Gentsch type, was used [8]. Its power of resolution permitted the mea- surement of very thin coverages. 135 Volume 129, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 22 August 1986 3. Results and discussion Formation of methane by the action of hydrogen on the carbon films is not observed (for the range mea- sured). The activity decreases with "aging". The reac- tion increases the process of clustering, possibly due to the presence of hydrogen, which weakens the Pt C bonds, increasing the superficial diffusion and diffu- sion on the substrate by elimination of the carbon atoms, forming encrusted particles and possibly a SMSIbond [9]. As can be observed in fig. 1, the specific adsorption (Ha molecules/atoms Pt) shows an increase with the degree of platinum coverage 0pf > 10"3 monolayers, reaches a maximum and then decreases sharply. The decrease sharpens with a rise in temperature. The ex- perimental points are the product of several series of measurements, for each of which a new carbon film was always applied. Comparison with curves of cata- lytic activity at the same temperature and covering shows that both increase proportionally and that the maxima are found with the same platinum coverage. (See fig.2.) In fig. 1 it may also be observed that measurement of the specific adsorption of Hz/Pt on glass, under comparable external conditions, is an order of magni- tude smaller than for Pt/C. Moreover it does not pos- sess the characteristics of the latter. This shows the in- fluence of the substrate and its interaction with the catalyzing metal particles. If the maxima of specific adsorption are represented as a function of the plati- num coverage, those with the most activity may be found from among the active particles. Moreover the conductivity of a Pt/C monolayer increases with in- creasing temperature and reaches a maximum near 30 C. Therefore an excellent analogy is found between the adsorption process and the conductivity behavior. A certain proportionality is also maintained. Fig. 3 represents the specific catalytic activity max- ima as a function of the platinum coverage. Their be- havior is different from that of adsorption. In this case other phenomena take place, such as the loss of car- bon in the process of methanization, as well as pro- cesses of deactivation by temperature and the presence of gases. These phenomena have been well character- ized in recent years by different methods [5,10]. 10-2 10'1 Pt coverage, 9 = 1 = 1.2 X 1015 atoms/cm2 Fig. 1. Specific hydrogen adsorption as a function of platinum coverage; solid lines, on carbon substrate; dashed lines, on glass sub- strate. 136 Volume 129, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 22 August 1986 0 2rf'30 50 e ^ PI = ZxW^TORR -2 10-' Pt coverage 10- 10-1 Fig. 2. Maximum hydrogen adsorption per platinum atom as a function of the Pt coverage. Temperature and pressure are indicated. These results permit concluding that the "aging" pro- cesses of the catalyst are related to the superficial dif- fusion of the platinum atoms due to the weakening of the bond produced by the presence of hydrogen, as well as the influence of the reaction itself, which elim- inates carbon atoms by the formation of methane near a platinum atom. Fig. 4 represents the dynamic pressure of hydrogen when the rate of methane formation is at a maximum, as a function of the platinum coverage. It can be ob- served that these results, despite being at different temperatures, tend to converge near values between 3 and 6 platinum monolayers. This shows that the method can predict results, as for example when the film behaves as a true metal. Similar results have been obtained by Egelhoff [11] by photoemission spectros- copy. Since it has not yet been possible with electron microscopy to investigate ultrathin metal layers with this degree of dispersion and to determine the average size of particles smaller than 10 A, the size distribu- tion of the particles was estimated by a statistical method related to adsorption measurements. The statistical calculations were made in accordance S. d t' -' 0 10 0 20" 30" 50 ./' \ 10" )0-2 Pt coverage 10- -Pt Fig. 3. Specific activity maxima as a function of the platinum coverage at different temperatures. Parameter: hydrogen pres- sure. Fig. 4. Dynamic pressure of hydrogen at the maximum rate of methane production, as a function of the platinum cover- age. 137 Volume 129, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 22 August 1986 with following hypotheses: no surface diffusion; con- densation coefficient equal to 1; adsorption on various sites and the number of possible adsorption sites vary- ing from 1 X 1015 to 20 X 1015 atoms/cm2. With these hypotheses the percentage of isolated atoms is ob- served to decrease with an increase in coverage. The percentage of atom pairs increase with coverage and then falls, the maximum being close to 0.1 mono- layers. Due to the fact that this model does not take into account growth kinetics, it was improved by con- sidering the model of Hamilton [12], according to the following hypotheses: active sites in which the atoms and other metal aggregates nucleate with the diffusion processes of the incident atoms taking place near these active sites. Under these conditions a relation is obtained expressing particle size, in terms of the aver- age number of atoms in a cluster, as a function of the incident platinum atoms vaporized on the carbon film. In this mode, for the purpose of estimating nu- cleation processes and superficial diffusion, the carbon film is considered to be a matrix intermediate between a graphite monocrystal and an amorphous carbon film. The average size of the most active particles can be es- timated from the latter calculation and the experimen- tal data. It can be observed from the specific adsorp- tion and the catalytic activity that the average size may vary from two platinum atoms (at 0 C) to a maximum of 10 atoms at 5 0 C. These values coincide with re- cently published results obtained by other more sophis- ticated methods [5,10]. Moreover, it is possible to es- timate the energies of activation for the processes of diffusion and cluster formation from these measure- ments, the values obtained being of the order of 5 kcal mol"1. This also explains the shift of the maxi- mum activities (for a given coverage) and adsorption toward higher temperatures in the range measured. Calculations also permit the estimation of the most active particles as the dimers, trimers and other larger particles with formation of the 84 and 85 site types. Coordination numbers of €7 are probable for the large catalytically active particles. The method permits the correlation of the results obtained by photoemission spectroscopy and by EXAFS. The changes in maximum HZ adsorption and maximum methane production/second with pressure and Pt/C coverage are in acceptable agreement with changes of band broadening observed in photoemis- sion spectroscopy upon increasing the coverage. The weakening of the bond with increased metal coverage also agrees with that observed by EXAFS method. 4. Conclusions From the results obtained it may be concluded that the platinum atoms are catalytically active, but are not the most active, those being dimers, trimers and larger particles with forms which present the maximum chemi adsorptive capacities, such as the 84 and 85 sites with an optimum activity of 10~6 methane molecules per platinum atom per second. References [1] O.L. Perez, D. Romeu and M.J. Yacaman, J. Catal. 79 (1983)240; P. GaUezot, Surface Sci. 106 (1981) 459; R. Kramer and H. Zuegg, J. Catal. 85 (1984) 530; G. Natanson, F. Amar and R.S. Berry, J. Chem. Phys. 78(1983) 399. [2] J.F. Hamilton, P.C. Logel and R.C. Baetzold, Thin Solid Films 32 (1976) 233; J. Andzelm, Surface Sci. 108 (1981) 561; G. Apai, J.F. Hamilton, J. Stohr and A. Thompson, Phys. Rev. Letters 43 (1979) 165; R.P. Messmer, Surface Sci. 106 (1981) 225. [3] J.F. Hamilton and P.C. Logel, Thin Solid Films 16 (1973) 49; 23 (1974); 29 (1975)'L24. [4] M. GMet and A. Renou, Surface Sci. 90 (1979) 91. [5] P. Lagarde, T.Murata, G. Vlaic et aL, J. CataL 84 (1983) 333. [6] H. Gentsh, N. Gufflen, V. Hartel and M. Kopp, Ber. Bun- senges. Physik. Chem. 77 (1973) 1023. [7] H. Gentsh, N. Gufflen and M. Kopp, Z. Physik. Chem. NF 82(1972)49. [8] H. Gentsh, Grossmann, N. Gufflen, M. Kopp and H. Rinne, Vakuumtechnik 23 (1974) 230. [9] S.J. Tauster, S.C. Fung, R.T.K. Baker and J.A. Horsley, Science 211 (1981) 1121; J.M. Herrmann and P. Pichat, Catalysis 78 (1982) 425. [10] R.C. Baetzold, M.G. Mason and J.F. Hamilton, J. Chem. Phys. 72 (1980) 366; R.T.K. Baker, E.B. Prestidge and R.L. Garten, J. Catal. 56 (1979)390. [11] W.F. EgglehoffJr. and G.C. Tibbetts, Phys. Rev. B19 (1979)5028. [12] J.F. Hamilton, D.R. Preuss and G.R. Apai, Surface Sci. 106 (1981) 146. 138 . Due to the fact that this model does not take into account growth kinetics, it was improved by con- sidering the model of Hamilton [12], according to the following hypotheses: active sites in which the atoms and other metal aggregates nucleate with the diffusion processes of the incident atoms taking place near these active sites. Under these conditions a relation is obtained expressing particle size, in terms of the aver- age number of atoms in a cluster, as a function of the incident platinum atoms vaporized on the carbon film. In this mode, for the purpose of estimating nu- cleation processes and superficial diffusion, the carbon film is considered to be a matrix intermediate between a graphite monocrystal and an amorphous carbon film. The average size of the most active particles can be es- timated from the latter calculation and the experimen- tal data. It can be observed from the specific adsorp- tion and the catalytic activity that the average size may vary from two platinum atoms (at 0 C) to a maximum of 10 atoms at 5 0 C. These values coincide with re- cently published results obtained by other more sophis- ticated methods [5,10]. Moreover, it is possible to es- timate the energies of activation for the processes of diffusion and cluster formation from these measure- ments, the values obtained being of the order of 5 kcal mol"1. This also explains the shift of the maxi- mum activities (for a given coverage) and adsorption toward higher temperatures in the range measured. Calculations also permit the estimation of the most active particles as the dimers, trimers and other larger particles with formation of the 84 and 85 site types. Coordination numbers of €7 are probable for the large catalytically active particles. The method permits the correlation of the results obtained by photoemission spectroscopy and by EXAFS. The changes in maximum HZ adsorption and maximum methane production/second with pressure and Pt/C coverage are in acceptable agreement with changes of band broadening observed in photoemis- sion spectroscopy upon increasing the coverage. The weakening of the bond with increased metal coverage also agrees with that observed by EXAFS method. 4. Conclusions From the results obtained it may be concluded that the platinum atoms are catalytically active, but are not the most active, those being dimers, trimers and larger particles with forms which present the maximum chemi adsorptive capacities, such as the 84 and 85 sites with an optimum activity of 10~6 methane molecules per platinum atom per second. Berry, J. Chem. Phys. 78(1983) 399. [2] J.F. Hamilton, P.C. Logel and R.C. Baetzold, Thin Solid Films 32 (1976) 233; J. Andzelm, Surface Sci. 108 (1981) 561; G. Apai, J.F. Hamilton, J. Stohr and A. Baker and J.A. Horsley, Science 211 (1981) 1121; J.M. Herrmann and P. Pichat, Catalysis 78 (1982) 425. [10] R.C. Baetzold, M.G. Mason and J.F. Hamilton, J. Chem. Phys. 72 (1980) 366; R.T.K. head.ce:title: Determination of particle size in the range below 10 Å for ultrathin films of Pt/C

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The phenomenon of clustering and its influence on the catalytic activity of the Pt/C system is studied. Coverages of the order of 1012 atoms/cm2 were used. Calculations permit the estimation of the most active particles as dimers and other large particles of the B4 and B5 site types.
